message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a foreign body in the left nasal cavity, which is confirmed by endoscopic examination. Therefore, foreign body extraction is the most appropriate next step in management. Transnasal puncture and stenting, adenoidectomy, and intranasal glucocorticoid therapy are not indicated for a foreign body in the nasal cavity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The foul-smelling discharge and blood-tinged fluid suggest a nasal foreign body. Foreign body extraction is the most appropriate next step in management. Transnasal puncture and stenting may be considered if there is an obstructive mass that cannot be removed via extraction. Adenoidectomy may be considered if there is chronic nasal discharge and/or mouth breathing due to enlarged adenoids. Intranasal glucocorticoid therapy is used for allergic rhinitis or nonallergic rhinitis with eosinophilia syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the given symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is a foreign body in the left nasal cavity. Transnasal puncture and stenting and adenoidectomy are not appropriate for this condition. Intranasal glucocorticoid therapy may help with inflammation but is not the primary treatment. Foreign body extraction is the most appropriate next step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The foul-smelling discharge from one nostril and mouth-breathing suggest the presence of a foreign body in the nasal cavity. Adenoidectomy is not indicated as there are no other signs of adenoid hypertrophy or chronic sinusitis. Intranasal glucocorticoid therapy is not indicated for a foreign body. Transnasal puncture and stenting are not necessary for a foreign body that can be easily extracted. Therefore, the most appropriate next step is foreign body extraction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest a foreign body lodged in the left nasal cavity. Foreign body extraction is the most appropriate next step in management. Transnasal puncture and stenting are not indicated in this case, and adenoidectomy and intranasal glucocorticoid therapy are not indicated for foreign bodies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The foul-smelling discharge and blood-tinged fluid suggest a possible nasal foreign body, which can cause obstruction and infection. Adenoidectomy and transnasal puncture and stenting are not appropriate without further investigation. Intranasal glucocorticoid therapy may be helpful for allergies and inflammation, but not for removing foreign bodies. Therefore, foreign body extraction is the most appropriate next step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and examination show a diagnosis of foreign body in the left nasal cavity. The most appropriate next step in management is foreign body extraction. Other options like transnasal puncture and stenting or adenoidectomy are not necessary for this diagnosis, and intranasal glucocorticoid therapy is not appropriate for a foreign body.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The foul-smelling discharge from the left nostril and mucopurulent discharge in the left nasal cavity suggest that there may be a foreign body present. Intranasal glucocorticoid therapy is used for allergies and not for foreign bodies. Adenoidectomy is not indicated at this time. Transnasal puncture and stenting is not appropriate since a foreign body is suspected. Foreign body extraction is the most appropriate next step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest a foreign body in the left nasal cavity. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is foreign body extraction. Transnasal puncture and stenting may be necessary for severe cases, but it is not the first-line therapy. Adenoidectomy may be considered if there is evidence of adenoid hypertrophy, but it is not related to the current symptoms. Intranasal glucocorticoid therapy is not appropriate for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest that the most likely diagnosis is a foreign body in the left nasal cavity. Therefore, foreign body extraction is the most appropriate next step in management. Transnasal puncture and stenting may be indicated for chronic sinusitis, while adenoidectomy may be indicated for recurrent acute otitis media or obstructive sleep apnea. Intranasal glucocorticoid therapy may be indicated for allergic rhinitis, but it is not appropriate in this case.
